repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of correspondence, writings (including notes, journals and manuscripts), artwork, photographs and audio cassettes which document the career of poet and translator David Gascoyne.

langmaterial.language: Materials in English and French, including Gascoyne's translations of French poetry into English.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Portions of the collection are microfilmed, as noted on individual folders.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Collection of documents acquired by gift and purchase from various sources. Source information is noted on the folders or in series descriptions. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The David Gascoyne Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: David Gascoyne Collection. General Collection of Rare Books and Manuscripts, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 24: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

bioghist.head: David Emery Gascoyne, 1916-2001
bioghist.p: The poet and translator David Emery Gascoyne was born October 10, 1916 in Harrow, England and died November 25, 2001. His early career was characterized by a precocious energy that produced two volumes of poetry ( Roman Balcony and Other Poems , 1932 and Man's Life is This Meat , 1936), a novel ( Opening Day , 1933) and a critical survey ( A Short Survey of Surrealism , 1935) by the time he was twenty. He became one of the leading representatives of British Surrealism and was an important liaison between French and British circles. His diaries from the late 1930s are particularly well known and provide an excellent picture of the Parisian avant-garde on the brink of the Second World War.

Gascoyne published several volumes of poetry in his early productive stage, but after 1956 he published little new poetry. His later work focused on lectures and appearances, essays, reviews, translations and the publication of his journals. His most criticially acclaimed later works include Night Thoughts and The Sun at Midnight . He also had a long-standing relationship with Enitharmon Press, founded in 1967 by Alan Clodd, which resulted in numerous publications.

Gascoyne's intense poetic sensitivity (often characterized as visionary or mystical) was tempered by severe depression and he devoted many years to recovery. It was during a stay at a hospital on the Isle of Wight that he met Judy Tyler Lewis, whom he married in 1975. He had four stepchildren.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into four series: Correspondence, Writings, Other Papers, and Alan Clodd Collection of David Gascoyne. The first three series are of mixed provenance, as indicated by accession numbers on individual folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The David Gascoyne collection encompasses accessions of single manuscripts and groups of manuscripts pertaining to David Gascoyne acquired by gift or purchase from various sources by the Beinecke Library.

The papers span most of Gascoyne's career from 1945 onward. The material from the 1940s is primarily correspondence, notebooks and journals, while later material from the 1970s through the1990s includes sound recordings, original artwork, typescripts and other material related to publication as well as notebooks.

Gascoyne's notebooks contain diverse genres of writings including notes and drafts for correspondence, prose, poetic writing, and lists (which are often bibliographic). In addition to traditional literary genres, Gascoyne's works include collections of found images and writings. One such collection, "A Little Book of Bits and Pieces," is bound into a volume; a second comprises a planned work entitled "Works of Novalis, Translated by Various Hands."

The bulk of the correspondence in the collection relates to the editing and publishing of Gascoyne's works and to the management of his literary career, though some addresses literary and philosophical topics. Other correspondence is personal, such as Gascoyne's postcards to his parents.

The largest single accession in the collection is that of Alan Clodd, Gascoyne's agent and publisher. In addition to correspondence, notebooks, artwork, photographs and audio recordings, the Alan Clodd collection includes papers from several volumes that Clodd helped prepare for publication, including Selected Prose , Selected Verse Translations and Gascoyne's planned publication Surrealism Resurveyed .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence covers topics which range from personal to literary to purely professional. All letters are incoming unless otherwise noted and all outgoing letters are holographs. Correspondence is also filed elsewhere in the collection (see the notebooks in Writings for drafts of correspondence and Correspondence for correspondence donated by Alan Clodd).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See: Lodwick, Sheila, incoming and outgoing

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series consists of two subseries: Notebooks and General Writings. Notebooks are arranged chronologically. General Writings are arranged by title of work. Some works (e.g. "The Sun at Midnight") appear in both subseries.
Additional notebooks and writings can be found in Series IV.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The notebooks contain poetry in a wide variety of styles (e.g. automatic writing and translated verse), drafts of correspondence, essays and reviews, and collections of found images. All notebooks are holographs.

Where applicable, notebook descriptions have been transcribed from the cover or first page of the notebook. These descriptions often reflect the predominant contents or theme of a notebook, but rarely reflect the complete contents. Folder notes identify titles of works only when they are readily apparent.

General Writings consist of holograph and typescript drafts related to the preparation of Gascoyne's work for potential publication. Of particular interest is a collection of found images, "Works of Novalis."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains collections of found images and writings, administrative papers, clippings and writings of others. The collections of found images and writings are clearly related to Gascoyne's surrealist writing, though no association with a particular work is evident

did.unittitle: Alan Clodd Collection of David Gascoyne

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series contains six subseries: Correspondence, Writings (including notebooks and general writings), Other Papers, Artwork, Photographs, and Audio Recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alan Clodd's collection contains not only papers resulting from his work as Gascoyne's publisher and agent, but also notebooks, artwork and family photographs, which were likely given to him by Gascoyne.

The Correspondence subseries consists of Alan Clodd's correspondence and David Gascoyne's correspondence. Alan Clodd's correspondence (incoming, outgoing and third party) relates to the publication of various of Gascoyne's works, to the management of Gascoyne's literary career and to Clodd's effort to secure an official honor for Gascoyne from the British government. Clodd's correspondence also contains several folders of letters and cards from Judy Gascoyne, which cover a range of personal and professional topics.

David Gascoyne's correspondence (incoming and outgoing) is primarily professional in nature, relating to appearances and publications. There are, however, personal letters inlcuding seven folders of postcards written by him to his parents Leslie and Winfred Gascoyne. Some correspondence related to the publication of specific works is filed in the Writings subseries, reflecting Clodd's arrangement of his papers.

The Writings subseries includes Notebooks, General Writings and Writings of Others. In addition to notes, drafts and typescripts, correspondence related to the publication of a particular work is filed here. Writings of Others include a typescript of Judy Gascoyne's memoir and material from several publications of Jeremy Reed.
Other Papers include clippings and reviews related to David Gascoyne.
The Artwork subseries consists mainly of gouache works on paper, all by David Gascoyne. Some are signed, titled or dated.

The Photographs subseries contains a few professional portraits of David Gascoyne, snapshots of Gascoyne and others and nineteen folders of Gascoyne family photographs. Subjects of the family photographs include David Gascoyne as a child and an adult, Gascoyne's parents, Gascoyne's younger twin brothers John and Tony (and their families) and Judy Gascoyne. Some of these photographs are identified with names, dates (ranging from the 1910s to the 1990s) or descriptions.
The Audio Recordings subseries consists of six audio cassettes containing recordings of David Gascoyne interviews, readings and performances.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries consists of Alan Clodd's correspondence and David Gacoyne's correspondence. Within each group, letters are arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent. Letters with only a first name identified and letters from unidentified correspondents or with illegible signatures are filed at the end of each group. Two folders of letters relating to the nomination of David Gascoyne for a public honor are filed at the end of Alan Clodd's correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of these approximately forty letters are addresed to the office of Prime Minister Tony Blair and express support of an official public honor for David Gascoyne. Authors include Sebastian Barker, Jeremy Reed and Roger Scott. These letters are accompanied by copies of letters from Alan Clodd to the letter writers.
